benchmark_details.name: MTOB (Machine Translation from One Book)
benchmark_details.overview: MTOB is a benchmark for learning to translate between English and Kalamang, a low-resource language with less than 200 speakers, using several hundred pages of field linguistics reference materials.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To serve as a testbed for language model capabilities and to expand access to language technology for underserved communities.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The task only tests sentence-level translation and may not be socially useful as it addresses translation between Kalamang and English, where all Kalamang speakers also speak Papuan Malay.

data.source: Documentation of the Kalamang language collected during fieldwork.
data.size: around 250,000 tokens in English and 25,000 tokens in Kalamang
data.annotation: Manual annotation based on linguistic fieldwork.

methodology.calculation: chrF measures character-level n-gram similarity between model outputs and reference translations.
methodology.interpretation: Scores indicate the quality of translation, with higher scores being better.
methodology.baseline_results: Human performance achieved chrF scores of 51.6 for Kalamang to English and 57.0 for English to Kalamang.
methodology.validation: Test set was created from randomly sampled parallel sentences.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: The dataset was constructed with community consent, and ethical considerations were taken into account.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: Informed consent was obtained from Kalamang community members for data use.
